thread.title: Online snack seller Graze expands into bricks-and-mortar stores with Sainsbury's deal
thread.title_full: Online snack seller Graze expands into bricks-and-mortar stores with Sainsbury's deal

title: Online snack seller Graze expands into bricks-and-mortar stores with Sainsbury's deal
text:
1,574.00 +24.00 
Range of 12 'healthier' snacks also to be offered by Boots and WH Smith (LSE: SMWH.L - news ) 
The snacks-by-post company Graze is to expand into shops after signing distribution deals with Sainsbury’s, Boots and WH Smith. 
In a departure from the company’s online-only and subscription selling roots, the agreements will see a Graze range of “healthier” snacks on sale in 1,200 stores nationwide. 
It marks the latest stage of an expansion push by Graze, which is controlled by the private equity firm Carlyle Group. In 2013 it introduced its snacks-by post service to the United States and in the year to the end of February reported a turnover of £68m , an increase of 31pc on the prior year. 
The company claims to enjoy “industry leading” underlying profitability, but has not yet reported figures for last year, when it invested in its American expansion. 
Anthony Fletcher, Graze’s chief executive, said its further expansion into bricks-and-mortar stores would allow it to reach new types of customers. 
He said: “It brings Graze one step closer to achieving our vision of becoming the number one healthier snacking brand in the UK.” 
Graze.com delivers snacks to your door 
Sainsbury’s said it will position the “tasty and more permissible” snacks next to tills to target impulse buyers who might ordinarily by tempted by chocolate or sweets. Branded “good to go”, Graze’s range of 12 products includes flapjacks, nuts and pretzels and will be priced between 99p and £1.49. 
The company said it had already trialled the products in Boots stores, where they had delivered the highest rate of sales of any snack and had proved popular with customers who do not often buy snacks. 
Graze was launched in the UK six years ago and now employs almost 500 staff. Carlyle took control in a management buyout in 2012, with Octopus Investments, DFJ Esprit and the management team each owning small stakes.
